description: Streamline user access: Log in once and access multiple applications seamlessly.

slides.title: What is SSO?
slides.content:
# One Key, Many Doors üîë

Single Sign-On allows a user to authenticate once and gain access to multiple related, but independent, software systems.

Example: Log into Gmail, and you are automatically logged into YouTube and Drive.

slides.title: Identity Provider (IdP)
slides.content:
# The Authority üèõÔ∏è

The central system that holds the user directory and verifies credentials.

Example: Okta, Auth0, Microsoft Azure AD, Google Identity.

slides.title: Service Provider (SP)
slides.content:
# The App üì±

The application the user wants to access (Slack, Zoom, Salesforce).

The SP trusts the IdP. "If Okta says you are John, then you are John."

slides.title: SAML
slides.content:
# Security Assertion Markup Language üìú

The Enterprise standard (XML-based).

1.  User visits App (SP).
2.  App redirects to IdP.
3.  User logins at IdP.
4.  IdP sends an XML **Assertion** back to App signed with a cert.
5.  App verifies signature.

slides.title: Standard Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which XML-based standard is most commonly used for Enterprise SSO?

slides.title: OIDC (OpenID Connect)
slides.content:
# Modern SSO ‚ö°

Built on OAuth 2.0 (JSON-based).

Mobile-friendly and simpler than SAML.

Uses **ID Tokens** (JWTs) to pass user information.

Dominating the consumer web (Google Sign-In).

slides.title: Federation
slides.content:
# Trust Bridges üåâ

SSO across different organizations.

Allowing students from University A to access Library Resources at University B using their University A credentials.

Requires a Federation Trust (e.g., Eduroam).

slides.title: LDAP / Active Directory
slides.content:
# The Source üóÑÔ∏è

Underneath the IdP, there is often a directory.

**LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol)** is the protocol used to query this user database (Active Directory).

slides.title: Social Login
slides.content:
# Consumer SSO üåê

"Log in with Facebook/GitHub".

This is just OIDC / OAuth 2.0.

Facebook is the IdP. Your app is the SP.

Reduces friction: Users hate creating new passwords.

slides.title: Pros & Cons
slides.content:
# Trade-offs ‚öñÔ∏è

**Pros:**
- Better UX (fewer logins).
- Fewer passwords to forget.
- Centralized control (IT can revoke access to 10 apps at once).

**Cons:**
- Single Point of Failure (If IdP is down, nobody logs in).

slides.title: Protocol Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which protocol is built on top of OAuth 2.0 and uses JWTs for identity?

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: SSO üéì

Unified Access.

- **IdP:** The Identity Provider (Okta).
- **SP:** Service Provider (App).
- **SAML:** XML Enterprise standard.
- **OIDC:** JSON Modern standard.
- **Social:** Login with Google.
